awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2023 IEEE Conference on Communications and Network Security (IEEE CNS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Network security is a key area of research in cybersecurity, and IEEE CNS is a highly respected conference in the field, attracting students, researchers and industry specialists from all over the world. The scope of research papers accepted to IEEE CNS range cover a wide range of topics in the general space of network security.

Providing support to students to attend IEEE CNS will provide knowledge sharing, increased visibility of the students’ research (and awareness by the students of others’ research), and career development opportunities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
IEEE CNS is a premier venue for communications and network security researchers to present their latest research. In 2023, the conference was held in Orlando, Florida, from October 2 to 5. It is the first in-person event post-pandemic, attracted over 100 participants from around the world, and accelrated active in-person discussions and exchanges of knowledge.

The project goal is to provide an excellent opportunity for students to learn about the latest research, developments, and trends in the field of communications and network security, by attending technical paper presentations, poster sessions, and panel discussions and through interacting with researchers and industry professionals to get their insights on the latest technologies and challenges. In addition to learning about the latest research, the conference aimed to provide students a chance to present their research or projects to other attendees, which can help them develop their communication and presentation skills. The conference also expected students to receive valuable feedback on their research from experts in the field. 

Supported by the NSF, IEEE CNS 2023 offered significant career development and learning opportunities, particularly benefiting 15 U.S.-based students with grants of $1,200 each. Six of these (40%) awards were granted to students from underrepresented groups, including women, minorities, and people with disabilities, who typically faced challenges in attending due to not having papers accepted at the conference. Selection for these grants was based on demonstrated interest in communications and network security, evidenced by research output, coursework, or project involvement.

This great opportunity was announced through multiple channels, with a highlight on NSF sponsorship and higher priority given to underrepresented groups.

Feedback from a post-conference survey was overwhelmingly positive, with 100% of student respondents affirming that NSF support was highly beneficial, and all agreeing that their participation at IEEE CNS 2023 significantly enhanced their research capabilities. They reported benefits from engaging in technical presentations, interacting with fellow researchers, and receiving valuable feedback on their work. All respondents indicated their intent to continue pursuing careers in communications and network security.


Last Modified: 05/24/2024
Modified by: Rhongho Jang
